dishonored is one of those games that starts out being pretty popular but gradually wanes in popular discussion. i think it's a fantastic game that, despite the bugs that preeminently exist in all bethesda games everywhere and for all time, is worth the time to play through it. there's a kind of morality system that affects how dark and brooding the end cinematic is, but that's the only thing you'd ever need to worry about as far as endgame is concerned. each mission is fairly self-contained, leaving you only to worry about the specific goals of that arc of the story. and the game's got gimmicks. but they're good gimmicks that are there for the whole game and serve a useful purpose. the dark powers your character can use let you teleport, turn invisible, see through walls, call up rats to eat people, etc., and it adds a whole new dimension to the standard 'sneak your way from one end of the map to the other' missions.

ehhhhhhhhhhh.. it's okay. i'm a huge fan of the bone comic's and i've read all of them at least fifty times. so, trust me, there are noticeable differences. otherwise, this is an okay adaptation. the characters look and sound as i thought they would excpt fone bone . most of the animations are pretty good. the graphics are really pretty. it's rather short. again, they cut out a lot. the gameplay puzzle portions are boring and just there to be there. and it was clearly ment for smaller children, and we all know how well it goes when telltale games tries to make a game for kids minecraftstorymode ! i think anyone older than the intended age would find this to be rather boring. otherwise, if you're a huge bone fan like me and want to play a game about it, i reccomend it. but, it's not worth it if you havn't read all the books yet. one other thing i should note is that there is another bone game in developement that will adapt all the books on gamejolt for free. i recommend checking that one out.

contracts was my introduction to the hitman series, and the creative license we were given to complete the job was the gift that kept on giving. depending on the weather, one could opt to be professional and keep things quiet or go on a sterling archer-esque rampage. absolution, however, decides to take that agency away and puts you in the uncomfortably tighter suit of a restrictive narrative, much like your mother did when you were flower boy at your uncle gerald's wedding. unfortunately, the aforementioned narrative is done in disappointingly poor taste, and absolution's linear nature does not lend itself well to multiple replays. filled with ghoulish, hideous caricatures which are supposed to pass some semblance of human beings, absolution catapults you into the grungy abyss of a metaphorical and at one point literal sex dungeon. it remains a competent stealth-action game and there's certainly some fun to be had if you're truly, desperately bored..but try as you might, you can't wash the smell of grindhouse out long after you've left.

i gotta say that this game is very enjoyable to kill some time and is a great lego game. pros rpg style of adventure -many characters to play -can start levels at different points -save and exit feature is really nice -all-around a fun game to play cons the rpg style they made super repetitive -there are so many random cinematics that just seem to old time. these random cinematics are unskippable and are very annoying as they pop-up every two minutes. these make the game unbearable at points. -pretty much the entire game is designed for two people because you need to switch between characters for every single mission over and over. this game is not worth the money whatsoever, i managed to get this game for off and is the only time you should ever buy this game. just seemed like they added content just because they needed more content, and not because it made the game more fun in any way. i 'd this game and it took me about hours, maybe less, being easily avoidable if you play two player which is a slap in the face for a solo player like me.

as it is, it is an unbalanced, near unplayable mess. i can clearly see the potential, but there is more to gaming that powerful enemies and poor starts. unfortunately, after deaths and no progress, i gave it up in disgust. the enemies are too powerful for the start of the game. even with the dog, you will only die painfully. hunger and thirst are so poorly balanced that you can die of dehydration in less than a day of doing nothing. loot is almost non-existant. in of my four runs, i got only one ranged weapon and ammo for it at the same time. most of the containers were empty, and the only food item i found was meat. no water means that you will not stand a chance. this is not a complete game. it should have gone on early access instead of being put out at full price. i hope the developers learn from their mistakes and make this game playable, because as it is i cannot enjoy it. there is a difference between a hard uet fun game, and an unfair and unplayable game.

pros - solid gameplay. - online works well. - relatively balanced characters. - game is pretty easy to start playing. cons - mileage may vary. heavily dependent on how dedicated you are to playing in a box. - taunting personal hatred - playing game with people who know what they're doing can be very disheartening. would i recommend this game to an ordinary person? not at all. the price is honestly insane. but would i recommend this game to a person who enjoys competitive games? yes.

as a person that enjoys turn based strategy games, i'm surprised i haven't played xcom sooner in my life. this game is absolutely fantastic. from the global strategy to manage your resources and assign develop a path to victory to the combat that showcases some of the better ai in the gaming industry. this is a game that never allows you a cheap victory. every battle you win is earned.

it's exactly like all the new 'open world' ea racing games. so if you like the classic ea formula with very few actual crash events.. this isn't even burnout. added insult to injury, the 'ultimate box' doesn't include all of the dlc's. it only includes of or so. it's a perfectly lukewarm game, therefore, i can not recommend it.

a classic rpg in the style of eye of the beholder and other first-person rpgs from the early ' s. there's about hours of content here, and its all worthwhile. much of the game involves trap puzzles. there is no grind or repetition here -- your character will progress at a reasonable rate to match the challenges of each level, and each level offers new and interesting challenges. the game has a retro feel with modern graphics, and doesn't drag on forever like many other rpgs. much of the fun involves hunting for secrets and there are many . there's essentially no replay value here, but your first playthrough will give you more than your money's worth. there are no unskippable cutscenes to destroy the fun.

it's a platinum action game so of course the combat is incredibly fun. there are loads of weapons for you to toy with on top of different characters to play. it's feels so good to hear the destruction in combat and watch the action unfold. it's short for one playthrough about hours or less? but the replayability reminds me of viewtiful joe. while short, you will want to keep getting better and better at the game to improve your rank. even if you don't improve too much, it's still fun to beat up a bunch of robots in this manner. at the same time, you are upgrading yourself in the process in this case, weapons and stats and making the next playthrough that much better. if you played a lot of viewtiful joe, you might scratch an itch with this game. it's a feeling i haven't felt since that game. edit unlocked magnus difficulty and yep, the game gets really interesting at this point. well worth multiple playthroughs.

it's time to save grandma from the clutches of evil. this follows the typical greatness that artifex mundi offers in all of its hidden object games. the graphics are great, the storyline is unnecessary, the voice acting is mediocre, but the fun of the puzzles and hidden object games are great. this game was short and fairly easy. i found the hidden object scenes weren't as typical as you would expect, while some were tough. the atypical hos were find an object, place it where it fits, which gives you another object and then find where that goes, and so on and so forth. it was a good break from the typical hos, but felt too easy. the puzzles were good, but nothing extravagant that made it too difficult to move forward. as usual easy achievements for those hunters out there. definitely recommend it if you love these types of games.

i bought this game because i expect to get the price back by selling the cards. i still gave the gameplay a try though and these are my findings upgrades are temporary, as in picking up the twin single shot cannons will give you about seconds of shooting them before going back to the single single-shot cannon. during this time however you can't pick up other weapon upgrades like the twin triple-shot cannons. some pickups give you random downgrades, as for example locking you into the horizontal or vertical axis at the point you currently are. while also temporary this can cause you to die pretty fast. overall it's a pretty bland space shooter, you go from left to right and shoot enemy ships until the level changes. now and then a boss appears but there really isn't much diversity as far as i can see. buy this if you want to sell the cards. do not buy this at full price. on the internet you can find free flash games with more depth than this.

while i loved the original ori and the blind forest's fantastic platforming, spledid visuals and wonderful soundtrack, the combat always felt more like a chore than an enjoyable diversion from platforming. thankfully the definitive edition remedies that one major complaint, and adds several new features such as fast travel and locations. black root burrows, one of the newly added areas, is considerable in size and took me almost three hours to completely explore. it also adds some welcome backstory to the characters in the game. the overall package is a huge step up from the original game, and one that i highly recommend for anyone who loves the metroidvania genre.

the artwork is pretty nice, but i couldn't get past the story. i'll bullet point - i get it, one character really likes food. they order lots of food. is that this vn's comedy? - is nadia a sexual predator? she basically found some random almost-naked girl on the street and her first response is to drag her to a movie and back to her place while giving no alternative sleeping arrangements. even though it's fantasy, i was just like 'um, ok?' - forced innuendo. i get it already. the game's going for the yuri audience. - a visual novel joke at an arcade? i know you're trying to be meta, but it was an extended joke in the wrong place. - i know there was the big page sprawl about rock and roll but like i just chuckled at the whole epiphany part where she suddenly draws out a guitar and it's like what's happening is a given even though her sister is using monsters to attack her and not any music. it's just like.. what's going on? i played up to there. i don't really want to play any more.

alan wake is most likely the best game i've played thus far that combines psychological horror with a heavily plot-driven storyline that leaves much to the players' interpretations. while it is true that other games have accomplished one or the other on their own, very few have successfully combined both for a lengthy gaming experience - with the only others in my mind being fatal frame and the early renditions of silent hill. if played on a higher difficulty, one truly experiences the definition of psychological horror a feeling of helplessness against the might of alan's dark enemies. the somewhat painful in a largely bad sense of the word sequences in the forests are offset by very great moments of the game, such as the concert and night life in bright falls. while the combat will eventually feel lacklustre, alan wake never fails to deter the suspense and interest that a game of this genre and caliber should generate. on a side note, i felt the change of gameplay and plot focus in american nightmare to be quite refreshing. sign me up for episode .

i'd heard various criticism of bioshock infinite and since i still haven't played the originals i wasn't really sure if this game would be very accessible. i just finished the main campaign and have to say that this game felt revolutionary, sort of how i felt after seeing star wars for the first time. the world is beautiful and very well-developed, and i love that there is a wide enough range of difficulty settings to let you experience the story even if you aren't a seasoned fps player. combat is fun and varied and generally avoids the feeling i get in some other games where you feel like you're just fighting wave after wave after wave. i also really liked the way that it encourages exploration yet keeping the game brisk. i was able to complete the main campaign in less time than it takes to finish a single player civilization game, which made it feel like it really didn't water anything down. i'm excited to go back and give the first bioshock a try and can't wait to see what ken levine and irrational put together next!

big issue with compatibilty, make sure you have the system requirements for this game before you go buying it. dark souls players who run vista will not be able to run this game which requires windows and dx , which sadly steam only offers the windows required version that doesn't support dx . on another note, dx players cannot play with dx - players. i would love to comment on the game itself but the problem stands against the fact the game splits it's players right down the middle. no hate on the game as a whole just it's overall setup and compatibilty.

whew where to begin with this thing. as always i'm a sucker for things with skill tree properties and open world games, but the game has faults that stopped me from playing half way into the game. i'm referring to the tab button for the map. it stopped working after hours of playing. looked at forums and saw that others had experienced the same problem, but way earlier than me, around september time when the game first came out. i bought it almost a month later not sure what exactly causes the problem. seems to be random or maybe it's when a player does a certain activity event motion that triggers this. a week after i see a post stating that they are finalizing the patch that fixes the map issue, but it'll be another couple weeks i don't know about others, but finalizing means that they are done and are ready to send it out for an update for players. recommend the game, but only until they fix this map issue.

although this game is a bit short, it was worth every penny. if you played trine amp , like i did, it takes a while to get used to the controls. but after that, this game is just awesome. the combat and puzzles are not to hard and not to easy. the d perspective brings another good thing to this game. i love it. the graphics are just awesome the game looks awesome. but the gameplay is a bit short. but because there is a possibilty to make mods and play mods i think there will we more user created content to download and play which makes it even more worth to play buy. the story, well that was just a dissappointment. it starts of soooooo well, but the ending just leaves you out in the blank. the developers dont know if they even complete the story because of the bad response low profit and high costs of the game. i suggest, you buy this game and have a good out of hours of fun. the mods. and support frozenbyte to develop some dlc's or a trine , to continue the story.

had to update my review after the considerable amount of hours spent in grim dawn. all i can say is i have found my favourite arpg. from the desolation of iron lore and disappointment from d , crate entertainment's grim dawn rose and stepped into the arpg hack amp slash scene, like the protagonist who steps in the nick of time to save the world. for such a incredibly low price, crate delivered a lot more than what the players paid. the flexibility of classes, the dark ambience, the challenging modes and last but not least the consistent updates from the developers contribute to what i can only say one of the best games ever made. fun fact crate entertainment has employees while diablo was worked on by at least blizzard employees, it's like pied piper vs hooli's hatch or whatever that they worked on.

simulated difficulty by stacking enemies. no tactical options. long tedious setups that result in same ai charge tactics with unlimited movement. character creation is designed for you to miss things along the way. stack for combat or get owned every step of the way. stack for skills and you will have a very rough time of it. go somewhere in the middle and you are creating a useless character. party roles are predetermined, cliche' an boring. sniper, medic, thief amd leader. anything outside that is bound to fail. skill system is not fleshed out. forces you to replay the same story with the same setup. they advertise the playthrough is different everytime..it's not..the loot is different..the story is not. they advertise your choices make a difference and have consequences. here are your choices are you powerful enough to kill whatever it is you off? if you are you get loot..if not you die. choice selection list over. this is a game that should be at best. wait for a sale on this one. it will be there soon. same song as most fan funded, greenlight and indie titles. lots of promises and no delivery.

summer addendum for smallworld . many of the horrible design choices, especially concerning the dismal online matchmaking, have been corrected and the game isn't broken anymore in that way, but it's still terribly glitchy and prone to crash. i doubt the developer's commitment to sparkle motion here probably never will work properly, which is amusing for a boardgame port. original review the board game itself is solid, casual multiplay, but jeeze is this version pretty lamely ported. originally a touch screen mobile game, this steam version looks nice but harbours some pretty dumb ux design choices and bugs that, mercifully, the developers have been patching from day one. it's a little broken, crashes and glitches out every now and then and people that just stop doing their turns or quit the game, aborting the match for everyone involved are still a huge problem as of feb .

its a nice mix of shadowrun returns and the newer xcom game. since its a mix of both, it lacks much of the story and rpg elements of shadowrun returns, and lacks a bit of the depth of the combat system of xcom. the result is a 'light' version of xcom set in a shadowrun world. its fun, its still going through its release issues, but its still enjoyable. if you have played shadowrun returns and ever wished 'man, i wish there was more combat' or if you have ever played xcom and said, 'i wish this took place in the shadowrun universe' then you will most likely enjoy this game. give it a few weeks or so for them to iron out the issues, the devs seem really dedicated to improving the game.

this game is probably appealing to many, but it reminded me way too much of what high school romance is like even though they are supposed to be in college . this game left me rolling my eyes, recognising all the dramatic subtext that i probably used myself at that age. this game also left me feeling dirty as if emily was insisting i or took advantage of her, when the entire game i remained aloof and as uninterested as i could be! it made me even more mad, because i felt it was she who was being pushy about coming out for the weekend. she was obviously on the rebound. i don't know, maybe teens will get more appreciation from this game. maybe even some adults. this is just one of the most disatisfying waste of time games i've played to date. on the plus side, i got all of the achievements in minutes.

terraria is that lightning in the bottle game you always wish would get the recognition it deserves, frequently bought for it's price and forgotten to the bottom of steam libraries. this game starts slow, feeling like a minecraft clone in d, slowly though, you uncover more and more to this game. 'oh, there's magic?' yup, 'boss fights that feel like super metroid or castlevania?' uh huh 'hold on, there are firearms including a minigun?' you ain't seen nothing yet. terraria opens itself up slowly, it's a nesting doll of excitement, just when you think the game has gotten ridiculous enough it just keeps adding more. from star cannons, to chainsaws, to spiderman web throwing. that is what makes this game feel so big while being so small. if you are a gamer that likes to mod to add more content, flavor, or mechanics. this is the game for you.

do not buy this game child of light must be played via uplay, ubisoft's service. this game is basically unplayable because it constantly has issues with save files. the game auto-saves and syncs with the ubisoft cloud at regular intervals. well it routinely loses save files - completely. after about hours of gameplay over several sessions i tried to open the game and continue my game and lo and behold - save files were missing. just gone. started the game again, played about an hour, came back later to continue from the save file and same problem - the save file is just gone again. a quick google search will tell you that this problem is pretty much universal. the game is unplayable because of save file issues and it seems to all be related to uplay. avoid this game which is a really nice game, such a shame and uplay like the plague, that's all i can say.

i can't say anything good about firefall over the last two years. things have gone from good, to great, then everything just tanked. the game went from engaging to nothing more than a grind. combat became extremely repetitive, even for a grinding game. i left firefall, and i'm not in the least sad about it. mark kern is making ember, a return to the riginal firefall formula that all of us old beta vets loved and cry ourselves to sleep missing. i've been in on firefall for going on two years now and i can only say good things about the game and the devs. the combat is slick and unique, the missions, although a little repetitive, are engaging and hard enough to keep even the most grind-weary player interested.

it's half a game - released in drips and drops along with new cash shop content to entice you to spend money while you wait for a full game. the content as is a maybe or days worth of fun - then you hit the level cap and find out all there is left ot do is grind one dungeon over and over and over or grind for pointless pets the allure of the mount and pet system fades after the first few dozen - pokemon this aint . or else you can participate in the worst mmo pvp ever concieved - imbalance gank fest of the highest order. the day the pvp patch came out which i and several in my guild were hoping for as a reason to stay was the death of that guild and the game for me. such a pity - this game had huge potential - but seriously these korean mmos need to stop the staggered release bullsh t and just release a whole game. aa - bdo - and now roi. this is my last korean mmo burn. im never spending money on anything from sk again.

a mix of ftl and homeworld, this game grabs much from both parent games, but can't really make the most out of it. - the combat is repetitive and the ai is pretty dumb. - the graphic style is good, but seems to be blurry and unsharp. - the maps are very small and the missions on them are repetitive also. fly there, cap that, destroy these, etc. - ships can shoot in any direction, fly in any direction etc. there is no maneuver, or allining the weapons toward the enemy, in other words, no tactic. - the 'rpg' element is pretty flat aswell. your ships progress after a few battles and can pick one of three perks then. conclusion this gmae literally lacks the depth it needs.

pros the gameplay is unique and clever, the plot is emotional and engaging, the music is fantastic, it's never too easy and always gives you a challenge, and i love the characters. cons the level design can be a tad annoying at times, the graphics aren't that good, i didn't mind that but some other people will and the true ending is very cryptic and is impossible to get without a guide not too mention insanely over the top difficult at the end. result but all those are minor issues and get destroyed by the pros. this is game is fantastic out of get it! tip if you want to get the true ending then when you obtain an item called the 'life pot' save it til you get to a place called the 'blood stained sanctuary' trust me it will help so much.

minutes is all it took for me to deduce that this game would be best suited for a young child. movement is slow, enemies pose no threat and merely provide something for you to stop and shoot to progress, and the background and foreground feature isn't even original. wario land on virtual boy did it back in . the devs knew how to make a game look good and make it function well, but they didn't know how to make it engaging. after just minutes of playing, my head was hanging to the side and my mouth was hung open as my brain cells realized they were no longer needed and went into standby mode. i know minutes isn't normally long enough to judge a product, but i don't need to eat an entire crap sandwich to know that i don't like the taste.

it's too short and quite easy tbh. a very easily attained weapon is nearly unstoppable after a couple upgrades. most of the mechanics of the game aren't necessary because you can just gun anything down. the intro is a little long for such a short game with only three islands to visit. storyline is predictable. coop is mission based only. no story mode coop. that all being said, i probably beat it in a few hours. i had fun, but was a little disappointed at how short and somewhat linear it was. if sales are generous, it could be worth it to you. i preordered it because i craved a zombie game around halloween.

ten dollars? eh, i've seen less substantial things sell for a lot more. still, i got it for five--- i suggest you do the same. pricing aside, this game is excellent. rudamentary on the surface, but extraordinarilly atmospheric. the musical score, while also simple, draws you into this little fantasy you'll feel like you're in a different world while your brain tightens as you pass through every corridor, through every rolling block. the concept of the game is intriguing as you are literally chasing the setting sun, getting powerups to stay in the light that keeps your ship powered, breathing a legitimate sense of adventure into the experience. it's a great challenge game to play a few rounds with your friends and try to break each other's records. if you're into fast-moving arcadish games, throw this one on your wishlist and wait for a sale.

ugh, what a mess. from the completely unintuitive controls to the inexplicable sound bugs and stuttering, you will find yourself dying death after unwarranted death, while you character does the exact opposite of your intention. i did complete the game, so be aware that a person who can get used to the strange and clunky control scheme could probably breeze through this game in - hours it took me just over . the graphics however are nice, and do a good job of drawing you into the game until you are ripped back out again by some technical faults of the game.

years ago when this game first came out, it was a fairly good shooter that stressed in game co-operation between players. now, after years of updates and modifications, the game sadly lacks the orginal feel of the game. game physics have plunged into the realm of the unbelievable, and server lag has become more than the occassional nuisance. sometimes pure luck is more important that player skill or team work. the developers chose to tweak the game difficulty by creating specials that can defy the very laws of gravity, etc, rather than fix known in game glitches that made the tanks easy to kill. also, it has been ? ? years since a new map was released for the game. add on maps are local host so you can imagine the issues with latency. unless you can get this game dirt cheap, or your a collector of the genre, seriously.. don't bother.

it's presented well, and there's certainly enough horror on offer to keep players entertained, yet somehow outlast fails to inflict the sort of mind-numbing terror that are the hallmarks of the f.e.a.r. and amnesia series. there are times when the game's brilliant - the mandatory chase scenes for example - but the rest of it feels like the horror presented is too overt, as if the developers were trying too hard. this isn't helped by a story that's difficult to become invested in and a main character who has less personality as the monsters you face. outlast is probably the best horror game of , and definitely worth a play if these sort of games are what you enjoy - but at the end of the day it just feels like it's lacking something.

started off real nice, everything you wanted in a mad max game, however its just a giant go collect garbage, not much more to it. story is pretty average, hours tops for the main story, the rest is collecting scrap to buy all your upgrades to continue the story real shame, can really see the devs were rushed, alot of content in the game hints that they were going to go much deeper eg the tools selection for max . one of the biggest problems is all the non-main story boss's all look the same, and fight the same but have different weaknesses, woo. would it be that hard to atleast skin them differently and give them a different weapon, seriously wtf. no big war rigs, big thumbs down for that stupid convoys made vehicle is just a pickup with a large gas tank, they even made the fury road truck prop in the game but as a wreck its in the northen tunnels near gas town.

a fun little management game that's unfortunately too padded out and loses steam the more you play. the game likes to surprise you with big events that you need to address --only they require you to be well-prepared before hand without any warning. it's easy to miss out on entire questline just because you didn't have enough detectives, even though the game has never given you any reason to hire more before. and once you miss these opportunities they are gone, unless you want to replay the entire last week. the game is too long and doesn't have any variety so you don't get much from replaying the game. once you reach a certain point halfway through the game you become so powerful it removes all challenge it once had. there's no point in trying to achieve anything more because nothing you do really matters. the game and the atmosphere started out pretty amazing, but as i was nearing the ending i just wanted it to end, but the ending didn't offer any payoff. it was just a 'that's it?'. whatever they tried to pull off there it didn't come across at all.

it's a game. thats the only real positive thing i can say about it. as far as a simulator goes it is very poorly designed and written out. the right and wrong choices are painfully obvious so theres no real trial and error to play. besides that the choices that would actually help you get out of depression are all blocked, as if everyone with depression has zero mental willpower to try and help themselves. overall my experience with this game has been very depressing indeed, the biggest letdown was the fact there was no suicidal option on the panels, as well as the fact the piano music was driving me insane to the point i had to turn off my speakers and risk not hearing the inevitable gunshot. i would not recommend this game as one to play seriously, but more as to show friends how bad it is.

horribly optimized. it barely runs on a machine built for modern gaming. if you're ok with fps and frequent crashing go ahead and buy it, otherwise it's just unplayable. if you do get it to work there's basically very little to do. there's an incredibly bland and hackenyed campaign and a scant handful of carbon-copy missions. the space combat is simplistic compared to other similar games, as is trading. the galaxy seems lifeless. there are tons of factions but you never get to know them and they never really signify. there are far better games in this genre, some of which are even free to play. it appears that the devs sunk all of their time into building a new engine for whatever reason and not nearly enough on making a game.

even though the 'release hype' is now over and this game has been hanging around for a while, i would still reccomend it. this game gets the balance of micro-management and general care of your city just right, with fun and captivating gameplay. a fantastic modding community comes with this game aswell, with literally thousands of items to add to your client to improve gameplay or simply make your city unique. as well as that the game is still being patched on a regular basis with the recent addition of european buildings, new maps, and tunnels for roads and walkways. the developers have also recently said that they will continue support for the game as long as they can. this game is certainly going to be around for a while and with such universal gameplay features and even more options added thanks to the mod community this game is certainly a great purchase with good value for money.

this game is fantastic and is basically the perfect mad max experience. the story is great, the gameplay is fun, there's tons of things to do on a massive map, there's lots of customization you can customize your car and you can even customize max! , the combat is good, there's little to no bugs, and not to mention the optimization is probably the best i've ever seen in a pc game, as it runs at a good fps on ultra settings. the game can be really challenging too, so don't expect surviving in the wasteland to be easy. it also doesn't tie in with any of the movies, so it's sort of just its own thing. only downside i really felt this game had was that it was pretty repetitive, but then again what aaa game released in the past years isn't? i highly recommend this game, it's a lot of fun and it's worth playing and will keep you entertained for hours.

i really want to feel like i can reccomend this game. the adaptive story is really kool, i love the visual style, and i respect what the developer was trying to do here. it's disturbing, it's detailed, and it certainly deserves the attention it's gotten, if not more. i've only got complaints. for one thing, the controls are awkward. this isn't such a big deal, it just feels a little clunky at times. the second complaint, on the other hand, is a deal breaker for me. this game is just not very scary. it's really not. even playing it at night, with headphones on and the lights off failed to scare me. don't get me wrong, it's got it's moments, but they are few and far-between. i never thought that playing a game about a man losing his grip on reality in the zombie apocalypse would bore me. maybe it gets better later on, but after giving it . hours to get good, i think it's reasonable to lose faith. it could still be your thing though, it's got a lot of promise. just didn't quite do it for me.

if your competative, and love to kill zombies in multiple ways, then look no further this game is for you. you have an excellent story mode, available to be played co-op with three other players but you also get competative online gaming, and even 'call of duty waw zombie mode' where you literally are thrown into a level, and told to survive for as long as possible. however unlike the cod version where you have 'rounds' this is a timed event with no breaks! how long can you survive? can you get gold? there is also a competative side, where you can play and battle against other players to do objectives, i.e. you can play storymode while being hunted by zombies that are players! you can also play a mode where your goal is to fill up a machine with gas, while players as zombies try to stop you. a worthwhile buy, great fun with friends and even with randomers.

if you just want to play the main game and stop there and ignore the postgame, then it's okay, i guess. nothing special though, but decent fun. some good atmosphere, some decent puzzles, a pretty decent-sized world to explore. the post-game, though, feels like something that was thrown together in a few hours and they didn't bother to test it or fine-tune it at all. it's easy to get stuck and have to warp back to the nexus, the challenges tend to be tedious and unfun without being really hard in a legitimate way, and the world loses a lot of its charm when you just want to friggin' be done already. i went from 'meh' to 'despise' on this game pretty quickly and i can't say i'd recommend it for a good gaming experience. oh yeah, and. the game is really pretentious and tries to be super creepy but it ends up trying way too hard and i'm so done with the 'spookiness' pretty quickly into it. gag me.

honestly, after playing this for a little while, it's a lot more clunky than most games of the genre type. the controls are clunkier, the fact that certain things require tools to get and it's automatic instead of organic in nature is a bit annoying. it's an okay game for something made in rpg maker yeah, i know the engines quite well having used them for the last, oh, years but it was always going to be clunkier than anything made in a more versatile engine. i mean, you could actually make something more like stardew valley using rpg maker but that would require a lot more effort than just making everything automatic based instead. i'm not sure i like this game much, sorry, but eh, i've played a lot worse. it's decent, just the whole lack of feeling like you have any control bugs me a lot. i like the hm and rf series and this is pretty inferior in comparison. not bad but not good either.

this game is good, i enjoyed playing it but probably wont be playing very much anymore, and here is why. matchmaking seems unbalanced. i got very lucky and opened diamond cards hearthstones legendary equivalent in the first week. it isn't enough facing opponents that are playing - legendary cards per game on top of the multitudes of rare and epics . the grind is real. you can earn only gold through quests, and ish through wins, which is equal to pack. i am getting burned out of the game before i can open new packs. the quests are fast, and will probably only play for the quests. but then i run into the first problem again, making me not want to play this is the biggest reason i dont feel like playing much anymore . i really dislike hearthstones free play model, and this feels very similar to it.

this game really is tremendous and one of my enjoyed games to date. from every game you play their is something to be learned and how to counter a problem you face or how quickly you should respond to certin threats. for example a british motor emplacment will obliterate your front line if you dont make the equipment squads to take it out. also hats off to the game makers for making a in game currency where you can buy dlc with that instead of plain cash. to all players who may want to buy this game, you will most likley get rekt in your first games, theirs alot to learn and how other people play. even with the hours i've spent on this game, a max rank will punish me if i'm not up to scratch. stategy is great, graphics are great. out of would use close the pocket ability and level the entire map destorying everything the enemy had, breaking the dead-lock and conceding defeat immediatly.

what a blast, literally! sanctum balances the tower defense and fps elements quite well, and never removes you from the first person view aside from that whole respawn delay thing if you manage to die . support towers allow you to pick up and place generated items like slow fields and mines even where towers wouldn't be allowed. up to players in a cooperative match also adds to the experience, and the difficulty scales or at least it seems to . if the game is too easy, or if you're looking for more end-game experience, you get credit for each 'feat of strength' earned by completing a level with the option turned on the feats are options for increasing the game difficulty, and can be used in any combination.

payday , or 'what happens when left dead meets point break movie'. not as good as the aforementioned valve title, it's still very enjoyable expecially if played with friends, and overkill updates the game very often so the time this game will become abandoned is yet to come. there are still some cheaters around, but overall if you want some hot shot action and a lot of upgradable weapons.. here you go.

fun and well-made, but it gets pretty samey. you fight the same handful of enemies in room after room, exploration seems pointless due to the lack of collectibles, unlockable moves feel like the same old thing in a new direction now you can attack up! , and the story is pretty generic bland. i've played for six hours and still feel like i'm in the early part of the game where you can't do anything yet. all that aside, the controls are tight, the combat is fun, the art is spot-on, and the costumes system is great. i like playing as samus aran in a beat-'em-up.

an unprecedented emotional experience. the game has a pretty unique relationship with what is known as the forth wall , not just making jokes with it, but even making game mechanics and plot points with it in baffling ways. every trope relating to rpgs and anything that frequently goes with them is brought up at some point. the uniquely strange writing does a great job at making the player laugh. the game also messes with your head a lot. the neutral ending boss made it feel like the game was playing me. assuming you're doing a true pacifist run, undertale is about finding humanity in unexpected places. the themes of the story are timeless, can be appreciated by all ages, and are well-executed. i know that gushing about this game has become a bit of a clich , but i went into it skeptical that it could be any good and came out feeling that this was the greatest work of art of the century. there are just no words anyone can type that do it justice. play it without spoilers. play it by yourself. play it without any sort of expectations.. in spite of my review.

fallout is a rpg in a post apocalyptic scenario. it also includes a pinch of fps elements. it brings you into a post-nuclear war washington dc in the former united states of america in some alternate ties in which you try to find your father. you will meet different factions, monsters, allies and tons of quests. while the main quests leads you more or less straight to the end of the game approx. - h, depending in your style the side quests add at least another more. the game has a rather high re-playability as your decisions on an action or in a conversation have direct influence how other entities behave towards you and how certain elements in the side as well as main quest change. the game is highly moddable and even though the graphics may seem somewhat outdated they match very nicely into the scenario and time. they can be enhanced by the mods as well. if you are into rpgs and into post apocalyptic scearios..this game is actually a must.

i really recommend terraria, because its a really in-depth game, and ive pretty much been playing since the first ever versions came out. i have it for all platforms console, mobile, and pc and its a very fun and time-consuming type of game, and if i had to compare it to another game like it, such as trove or minecraft, i would definately put it first. the only real downside to this game, and its not even that bad is that for the longest time, my terraria stopped working for pc, and it kept crashing on my phone, but other than that, its just fine. so, if your looking to buy this game for any platform, i strongly suggest it, and yet.. im a young girl that lives way down in the southern shots of the us. buy this game if you havent already!!

interesting game mechanics similar to far cry in the aspect of taking over strongholds and other various points on the map however that's pretty much all you end up doing area's may look different but it's a rehash of the same events. this game sadly fails to capture the grittiness of the previous title which is a missed opportunity on the developers part. you geniunely feel no attachment to any character or the struggles america is going through this entire game. as the previous title you had a lot of gut churning moments at how monsterious an invading force can be however it's downfall was how short the game was. despite it being free over the weekend i personally have played enough to say i won't be purchasing the game as i've experienced all the game has to offer for me, i didn't have a chance to play the multiplayer aspect of it but i don't feel like i am missing out on much, i'd say it's a out of kept my attention for a bit and the appeal wore off shortly after.

the first thing to know is that this isn't xcom. it is made by the same company, but it is a spin off that is attempting to break new ground and take the tactic and strategical components from the main franchise and transition them to a first person shooter. it.. i mean it exists. to be frank, this is neither a good nor bad game. it's just kinda there. the buereau ends up being a third person shooter with strategic elements tacted on. playing on the lower levels, there was zero motivation to even utilize these strategic options. there are a couple side quests at the hub and some very light rpg elements, further muddling what this game is. i'm forced to ask who this game is made for. it does everything. a fan of just about every genre could be it up and say, 'this is.. okay?' this is a simple case of trying to please everyone resulting in inability shine any one area to an acceptable quality. like i said, it is niether bad nor good. but is that really worth your time?

this is not your normal x or rts game. it can be very hard. the problem is the way the ai enemy behaves or reacts to your success. a normal person used to normal games of that type will be inclined to conquer as many planetary systems as possible. but the way the game is designed, this only makes the ai send larger and larger waves of atackers. and since there is a cap to the number of units you can have, you are quickly overwhelmed. its so frustrating to be punished for success. so since its not a bug but a deliberate design choice, stay away if you dont like games like that. i like to steamroll and overwhelm my enemy but its not possible in this game. you have to be lean and mean, and i'm not fond of that tactic

i don't mind permanent unlocks in my rogue-like, but this isn't how you do it. in traditional 'proper' rogue-likes you could win the game on your first attempt, but you won't, because you lack the knowledge required that comes from your previous attempts. in shattered planet you could never win on your first attempt, because you need to unlock permanent stat upgrades that are acquired by playing, collecting a few resources to buy upgrades, and then dying and starting over again. this fundamentally breaks a large part of what makes rogue-like games compelling, your skill and knowledge counts for nothing against the need to grind. the graphics are quite nice, and i like the idea of being perpetually pushed forward by the encroaching corruption, but the mechanics ruin it. maybe you can reach a point where you have capped the stats, and then it's just your wits vs the game, but i'm not prepared to grind it out to find out. see also vinraith's steam review .

this game completely took me by surprise. i bought it a while ago and started it and had fun but then forgot about it.i recently began playing it and i highly recommend it. easily one of the most graphically impressive games, it borrows a bit from uncharted but definitely does it better. while the actual 'tomb raiding' takes a backseat, gameplay is absolutely satisyfing as you explore an open world island and fight your way through a crazed cult to find your shipwrecked crewmates. the voice acting is great, lara's voice actress specifically standing out. the scope here is cinematic, with huge set pieces that never detract or take away from interactivity. there are tombs to raid but not nearly as grand or comparable to the original games. there are many collectiables to be found in the form of manuscripts, letters, treasures artifacts, etc. with a robust skill and weapon upgrading system don't try to make sense of how decades old weapons suddenly become new iterations, just enjoy! , combat always packs a satisfying punch. quicktime events can be a little wonky at times, maybe it's just me, out of

i enjoyed the earlier pixel puzzles games, and looked forward to this one. i found the earlier games fun and relaxing in no zombie mode, at least . this one is mostly aggravating. i do love the fact that your puzzle progress is saved. i'm neutral on the addition of rotation. it does add a challenge and is fine for the pictures where you can make a reasonable guess about the orientation. i don't like the dimming of the floating pieces. you only see the actual colors after you pick up a piece. and i could do without the picture of a hawk killing a seabird. but what really ruins the game for me is the table you build the puzzle on. it is so strongly patterned and colored that it's very hard to see the shapes of the puzzle pieces against it. you can change the color of the table, which doesn't help enough. it would be best if you could switch to a solid color background.

gemini rue is a point-and-click game, with a furturistic-noir feel to it. the dark and mysterious atmosphere created by the extremely good soundtrack, gorgeous visuals and outstanding voice acting create a world that immerses you on such a high level you forget you are sitting in front of a computer. just because this is a point-and-click game, does not mean that it's a game for kids or noobs. there are gunfights, which are both intense and challenging to play as ammo is limited and you can only take shots. lack of quick-thinking will lead to death. the plot line is in no way cliche, it is paced out extremely well and characters are interesting, accompanied by the excellent voice acting. the hints and information build up on a very solid story, and the plot twist is unpredictable, punchy, and shocking - the elements of a perfect plot twist. as you travel through this hour game as azriel odin, trying to find his lost brother or delta- trying to escape. dark, immersive out of goty

so.. the procedural algorithm used in no man's sky pretty much sucks all of the planets are mostly the same. same terrain, same plants, same rocks, same cave systems. only the atmospheres and animals vary. what's even worse is that exploring all of these similar planets makes up about of the game. ships, combat, space stations, aliens, customizing your stuff, and getting to the center of the galaxy all seem like nothing more than an afterthought, all lumped into that last . the game is really fun, for about a week if that . after that, it's just a grind. a grind which, as far as i can tell, has no reward worthy of the time required for it.

i'm going to go against the grain here and say this is not a game that you should be spending on. it is the exact same thing over and over again, from the very first mission to the very last. this game is a repetitive stress injury waiting to happen with all of the constant clicking to attack and spinning your mouse if you don't choose to use a controller . bland and boring enemies that really present no challenge other than there being so many of them or, in the case of the gutter rat, being able to get the surprise on you. there isn't currently any subscription or dlc or in-app purchases, so i'm not sure how they expect to properly monetize this so they can provide the numerous updates and additions that it needs. i'm sure there will be plenty of dc sooner or later, but until then, you get heroes and or so levels to replay hundreds of times.

this is probably the worst pc port i've seen and that's such a shame! i'm running two gtx titan's in sli on an asus rog swift hz with g-sync and i'm running the game off two ssd's in raid . i'm seeing about usage on both cards so basiclly, the game runs like crap! even with g-sync, i'm seeing notiable frame drops averages about fps when in the batmobile . oh and it's capped at fps, which can only be changed in an .ini file! this was my most anticipated game of but it's just unplayable atm, i'm very disapointed in rocksteady for thinking that this was ready for launch on pc and nvidia for branding this as a 'way it's ment to be played' game. bassicly what nvidia is saying there is that fps is the way you're ment to play games on pc so go swap your titans for a ti as it's better!

the single player story is weak and uninsprring and locked into an imperium only view. but i didn't purchase the game for the single player experience, i wanted multiplayer ship battles against my friends and new foes on the internet. after paying my i'm not allowed to have a multiplayer experience. there is no way to play against your friends. the best you can do is team up and get half the usual points and ships just to fight two random opponents on the internet. you cannot jump in and play this game in multiplayer. you are forced to grind for hours to unlock all the content and ships for each race. that will be hours of grinding to unlock all the races. if you want to fight the ai you are still forced to grind again for each race, and again for each difficulty level. when the developers were questioned about this they affirmed there is no intention to allow you to play multiplayer without being forcing grinding to unlock the content that you've paid for.

i've just completed this game and i can't recommend it at all. this abomination of a game disguises itself with the day of the tentacle graphics, but is really an exercise in frustration. the basis of this game, the physics engine, is highly unreliable. nearly every advanced procedure becomes a gamble. the checkpoint which is a bad system to start with saves neither your level time nor your dimension change count. this means every level up to five minutes with required changes and really tough time challenges has to be done in one go to get the achievements. you'll waste a insane amount of time. one of the worst 'gaming' experiences of my life. do not buy this game. p.s. believe it or not. the dlc's are even worse. you'll just want to punch the devs in the face, really really hard..

the system requirements are total lies. unless you have a gb , you will get fps. bad match making due to low population because they decided to release this game during overwatch beta. single player is maps, with difficulties and frankly they are a snooze to breeze through. you will get bored the nd time through. i expected a lot more from gearbox. i hope they fix it, because it really feels like they rushed this out the door. really sad, i wanted to like this game.

i've played every single ac game since the first, and this one is definitely the best since ac i'm not sure if anything can beat ac . the world is massive, there are various cities and towns dotted across the map rather than just a few big ones ..and these cities towns are still pretty big and cool to run around in. the real eye-candy are the islands that are literally everywhere on the world map. even the small, miniscule islands are absolutely gorgeous and are worth exploring. the water, the weather, the day night cycles, everything graphical in this is just amazing to look at. and the main character is finally likable in an ac game again. connor in ac was just annoying to me, so ezio was the last really likable character in the series. edward is a bit of an anti-hero, but that's what makes him likable. not only is the acting done really well, but he has no issues with doing what he pleases for whatever he wants..as you would expect a pirate to be like. so yes, great title and very worth the buy

hey guys, remember we said we were offering free stuff for crimefest? lol we lied you get microtransactions instead you pieces of . never expect anything nice from us again. in all seriousness, a brief reason why microtransactions here are unjustifiable and why this deserves boycottting -several previous statements saying they wouldn't put microtransactions in -stat boosting skins which will give a gun an edge over someone elses gun -apparently, most guns have been nerfed in such a way that you need the stat boosts to get them up again -some guns have been massively buffed -crimefest said the community would get free stuff -the safes you get take up a card drop. so instead of ingame money, or masks, or colors, or textures, or the stuff that people actually want from a card drop, you can get something you have to pay money to use. in a game with around worth of dlc yourselves on a ing nuke overkill

the story is great and all but act feels really rushed. like how vella's family is suddenly friends with those cloud people she randomly met when shay visits the cloud. when did they even get there? how did they get so close? why did the developers recycle the same characters and scenery? and once you finish act one the puzzles are just impossible to figure out. even the solutions make very little sense when you find them in a guide. i only checked the community guides once or twice for act but i need to constantly tab out to them for act , which i've only finished half of so far because it gets so frustrating all the time. it could have been done so much better but they rushed it instead. ugh. so anyway, i would only reccomend this if you're buying it on sale and don't mind having to check a guide every now and then. if you enjoyed other double fine games like stacking then you'll love act one because the puzzle difficulty is about the same. otherwise nope.

dandelion is a wonderful game. it deals a lot with depression and loneliness. the story is well thought out and well written and allows for a great deal of play time. the gameplay it's self is not my favorite, i find the 'choosing what you do for the day' mechanic to be kind of boring and a waste of time. the story has a lot of mysteries to it that slowly unfold as you play through, dealing both with the main character's personal problems that she needs to work through, and the guy's stories. something i don't care for is that have to choose who you want to pursue fairly early in the game before you've actually had much time to get and know them. you do not get to interact with them as humans until you've decided, which is a little annoying. it doesn't matter much on secondary playthroughs, but on the first playthrough it feels like you just have to guess as to who you're going to like.

blue shift has one of the most horrible single player games ever. i had more fun playing the free single player games in hl mods such as azure sheep very good and case closed super short, though better than bs . do not buy this game! having played tons of free mods and opposing force, blue shift sucks big time. opposing force gives you cool new guns -- buy that instead if you really want to. blue shift was clearly phoned in as a project and that's why it sold poorly. the only good thing that bs added to hl was better quality textures, which you will get anyway if you buy any hl product. there is no reason to buy this garbage. it has a promising beginning and a new security guard model, though it is downhill from there. don't let this game be a downhill of your wallet. all i can remember from this game is that it was frustrating and boring as hell and it ends suddenly as if the budget ran out. it is even worse than gunman chronicles, a retail half-life game too weak to get on steam.

i recommend this game even if you haven't played withcer . the game is so good, that it fills the gaps and make you aware of what you have forgotten or of what you just don't know. i really recommend this game, and the amount of hours i have played it can agree with me. people say the replayability is very high. i disagree. by the end of the game, you are tired of the same gameplay over and over. the way you fight is always the same and you can't play with different characters, such as in skyrim, but it is the way that this story is written and told that makes it unique and so likeable. and you can sellect different paths throught the game. i really recommend it. there's nothing else to say. if you have enough money, buy it. it's totally worth it.

apb all points bulletin , the first online game developed by david jones, the creator of the grand theft auto franchise, is a massively multiplayer online game based in living, breathing cities that will feel familiar to players, as they precisely replicate famous cities all over the world. apb is a turf war involving two main factions, the squads, whose goal is to uphold the law, and the gangs, who seek to break the law at all costs. players will be able to choose their side, in a classic good guy versus bad guy scenario.

this game is pretty much a graphically updated version of age of wushu. from what i've seen, you can pretty much complete the entire game just clicking on the quest objective. no need to learn new moves - as there is no option to learn new moves. oh, and the ease of leveling up? level in less than hours of gameplay. one key thing of advice - if you want to see what you're doing, or rather the game's scenery, i recommend windowed-mode, and clicking the little square in the corner maximize to get rid of the giant ink blot hint marker.. oh yeah - there is no option to rid yourself of the hint marker. if you are a gamer who doesn't understand the game he she's playing within hours of gameplay, sure - this is the game for you. if you're like everyone else - stay away from this game like it's the plague.

sword coast legends would appear to have the right stuff at first glance. but down to the core just doesn't feel like d amp d in the same way neverwinter nights did. i'd consider the interface and gameplay kind of kludgy. it all feels rushed to me. i'd really like to say the time i spent with this game was fun. i only played during the free weekend and ultimately i didn't feel like forking over the to keep playing.
